title: Add meta transaction extension for ERC721 approvals
body:
**üßê Motivation**

There will be a bounty for this feature on Gitcoin.

The motivation for this feature is to give NFT owners the ability to sell or trade their tokens without owning ether.

**üìù Details**

Right now, NFT owners can sell their tokens without gas by using a decentralized exchange (e.g., an exchange built on 0x Protocol). However, these exchanges require that the token owner sets approval in the ERC721 contract for their exchange contract. A user without ether can't set the approval.

If the ERC721 contract supported meta transactions for the setApprovalForAll() function, a user would be able to both receive a token and then sell it without owning ether because the exchange could securely set approval on the user's behalf. This feature could enable an improved on-boarding and user experience for people without ether who are interested in NFTs.

Issue Status: 1. **Open** 2. Started 3. Submitted 4. Done

Does this mean ERC721 contract  pay the gas?

Issue Status: 1. Open 2. **Cancelled** 

<hr>

__Work has been started__.


These users each claimed they can complete the work by 2¬†years, 10¬†months ago.
Please review their action plans below:


**1) [pvienhage](https://gitcoin.co/pvienhage) has been approved to start work.**

Hi, here are the steps I would take to fuffill this bounty:
(1) Write a technical specification for ERC721 metatransaction approvals and transfers
(2) Submit that specification to the funder and work with them to make sure it fits all of their requirements.
(3) Write an extension of the standard ERC721 contract which contains meta transactions.
I'm a smart contract auditor with extensive experience with the pitfalls of signature implementations (replay attacks, transaction malleability, ect) I can produce a secure efficient version of the ERC721 standard which includes meta approvals and meta transfers.

Learn more [on the Gitcoin Issue Details page](https://gitcoin.co/issue/openzeppelin/openzeppelin-solidity/1596/2092).

Hi Cyrus,
(1) I've got a fairly large library of public things I have built here's a gist of some hyper optimized assembly I just wrote for spec256r onchain signature verification https://gist.github.com/pvienhage/19211ec45dde57168d6c13ff119f75c8 it isn't very readable solidity though haha. Here's a signature based CTF I wrote https://etherscan.io/address/0x7cd03C9f1D2dc95358B1992e9afc857aeaab45D5. I also have several public audits mostly under the Authio brand. Here's one of a decentralized exchange which implemented meta transactions for their internal ERC20 token https://authio.org/audits/coinvest-v3
(2) So it is fairly straight forward to add methods which take signed data to preform the functions of an ERC720 contract on behalf of someone else. I'm 100% confident that I can write code which can do approvals and transfers for an account holding 1 nft and 0 eth, assuming someone with eth sends the transaction. I'm not sure how it will integrate with the current codebase of the 0x exchange, because I haven't really reviewed it.

@CyrusL  Hi, I have started drafting the code. Here is the specification of what I think would be the best solution to the problem: Edit the ERC721.sol contract in the tokens/ERC721 directory to contain the methods delegated_approve, delegated_approveForAll and delegated_safeTransferFrom which will take the same inputs as the non delegated versions plus a signer address and a signature. The signer will need to sign a nonce for their address hashed with the address of the token and the input data. Then the methods will behave as if the signer called them. I had initially proposed an extension of ERC721 but the mappings in the ERC721 are private so cannot be accessed directly by contracts which inherit from it and there are no internal approve methods.  
If this sounds good to you I can deliver the code, otherwise let me know and I can change what I will build. Thanks!

@pvienhage After a quick Googling, it looks like 0x Protocol solves this problem by using a unique salt per order: https://github.com/0xProject/0x-protocol-specification/blob/master/v2/v2-specification.md#erc721proxy . I'm not sure if I'm understanding the issue correctly, but I wanted to include the link in case it's useful.

Hi @CyrusL great! 
I had planned on having a mapping in the contract from addresses to uints with the requirement that the nonce be the one in the mapping. I hadn't seen the random salt method before but it could help with throughput and mean you don't need to do lookups for nonces from your offchain application. It's up to you as to which you'd prefer as I think either could work well :)

@CyrusL Here's the nonce version https://gist.github.com/pvienhage/2bbd2e6aa8e46e7f83fb33100b82747d and here's the salt version https://gist.github.com/pvienhage/9b24892d4814dfbd663efe8384bb38b2
Let me know which one you prefer and if you have any changes you would like me to make and I can start the submission process for openzepplin
@pvienhage Ok cool thanks. Is there a way I can communicate with you to ask a few outside of this Github thread?
Sure I have a telegram @pvienhage and discord @pvienhage#5066 we could also use email pevienhage@gmail.com
Would love to help out with this if you guys need anything! I'm @austingriffith on telegram.

@pvienhage Hello from Gitcoin Core - are you still working on this issue? Please submit a WIP PR or comment back within the next 3 days or you will be removed from this ticket and it will be returned to an ‚ÄòOpen‚Äô status. Please let us know if you have questions!

* [ ] escalation to mods (6 days)

While we do want to add support for metatransactions, this seems too ad-hoc: we will move forward with a more full-fledged solution, e.g. something like TabooKey's solution: https://medium.com/tabookey/1-800-ethereum-gas-stations-network-for-toll-free-transactions-4bbfc03a0a56
